Counter-Strike 2 Prime is a masterclass in how to take a legendary franchise and grind it into a soulless, greedy, corporate money funnel that actively disrespects the people who keep it alive. I genuinely cannot overstate how angry it makes me that Valve has the nerve to advertise ‚Äúfree rewards‚Äù while forcing players to pay real money just to access them. That is not a perk. That is not a bonus. That is a scam wrapped in PR language.

Let me spell it out slowly since Valve seems to think players are idiots:
If I have to pay first, it is not free.
Not even a little.
Not spiritually.
Not philosophically.
Not in any universe where words still mean things.

Prime is not an upgrade‚Äîit‚Äôs a shakedown. You‚Äôre not paying for value, you‚Äôre paying to remove artificial restrictions that never needed to exist in the first place. Valve created a problem and then sold the solution, all while smiling and pretending they‚Äôre doing you a favor. That‚Äôs not game design. That‚Äôs extortion with extra steps.

And what do you get after paying? Excitement? Satisfaction? Respect?
No.
You get the privilege of grinding your time away for ‚Äúrewards‚Äù that are usually worthless, forgettable, or instantly thrown onto the pile of digital trash. You pay money to unlock the chance to maybe get something someday, as long as you keep playing, keep queuing, keep feeding the machine. It‚Äôs manipulative, cynical, and exhausting.

What makes this rage-inducing is that Counter-Strike didn‚Äôt need any of this. CS was built on pure gameplay‚Äîaim, strategy, teamwork. That‚Äôs it. No gimmicks. No psychological monetization tricks. Now it feels like Valve looked at that legacy and said, ‚ÄúCool, but how do we squeeze more money out of them for doing the same thing?‚Äù

And yes, the money matters. When I‚Äôm forced to hand over cash just to access features dressed up as ‚Äúfree,‚Äù I can‚Äôt ignore the bigger picture. Massive corporations don‚Äôt just sit on piles of money‚Äîthey move it, invest it, and interact with governments and political systems around the world. As a player, it‚Äôs infuriating to think that money pried out of gamers through deceptive monetization could be feeding into political structures I strongly oppose, including the Israeli government. Even the possibility that my frustration-funded purchase contributes to that makes the entire Prime system feel even more disgusting.

This isn‚Äôt about supporting developers. This isn‚Äôt about funding innovation. This is about conditioning players to accept that nothing is earned anymore unless you pay first, and even then, you‚Äôre expected to be grateful for scraps. Valve doesn‚Äôt communicate. They don‚Äôt justify. They just normalize it and wait for players to stop complaining.

Prime doesn‚Äôt make the game better. It makes it uglier. It divides the player base, cheapens progression, and constantly reminds you that you‚Äôre not a valued community member‚Äîyou‚Äôre a revenue stream. Every time the game dangles a ‚Äúreward,‚Äù it feels less like appreciation and more like a leash.

Counter-Strike 2 Prime is not premium. It‚Äôs predatory. It‚Äôs misleading. It‚Äôs corporate arrogance disguised as a feature. Paying money to unlock ‚Äúfree‚Äù rewards is one of the most insulting contradictions in modern gaming, and the fact that Valve gets away with it shows just how low the bar has sunk.

I didn‚Äôt buy Prime because I wanted to.
I bought it because the game punished me for not having it.
And that‚Äôs the part that makes me angry enough to write this in the first place.

Timeless Gameplay and Constant Evolution
I‚Äôve been playing Counter-Strike for years, and one of the things that keeps me coming back is how consistently the game evolves. Developers have done a solid job of updating mechanics to maintain balance between the two opposing forces‚ÄîTerrorists vs. Counter-Terrorists. This constant fine-tuning ensures matches remain fair and competitive, a sentiment echoed by many players who describe CS as ‚Äúthe purest FPS experience out there‚Äù.
Weapons, Customization, and Fairness
The arsenal of weapons and customization options is vast, offering variety without tipping into a pay-to-win scheme. Skins and cosmetics are purely aesthetic, which makes the game appealing without compromising fairness. As one Steam review notes, ‚ÄúNo predatory cosmetic system, no fancy and distracting graphics‚Ä¶ this game is simply the purest FPS experience‚Äù. That‚Äôs exactly how it feels‚Äîyour skill matters more than your wallet.
Community Challenges: Hacking and Mods
Like any competitive online game, hacking exists‚Äîwalling, aim assists, and similar exploits‚Äîbut Valve‚Äôs anti-cheat efforts keep them to a minimum. While not perfect, the developer team actively works to preserve integrity. On the content side, CS doesn‚Äôt chase trends like battle royale or tower defense modes. Personally, I don‚Äôt miss them, but it‚Äôs worth noting for players who crave those experiences.
Maps: Quality Over Quantity
If there‚Äôs one area I‚Äôd love to see expanded, it‚Äôs map variety. New maps take time to arrive, and understandably so‚Äîbalancing them for competitive play is no easy task. Still, more options would add freshness to the rotation. Many players agree that while the core maps are iconic, expanding the pool would enhance replayability.

Counter-Strike 2 is a fantastic evolution of a legendary game. It keeps everything that made CS so addictive while upgrading it with modern visuals, smoother performance, and smarter mechanics. The new Source 2 engine makes maps feel more alive, gunplay more responsive, and movement cleaner than ever.

The updated smoke physics add a whole new layer of strategy, making every round more dynamic and skill-based. Matches feel intense, competitive, and rewarding, especially when playing with a coordinated team. CS2 still demands precision, game sense, and teamwork, which is exactly why it remains one of the best tactical shooters out there.

Overall, Counter-Strike 2 respects its roots while pushing the series forward. Whether you‚Äôre a long-time CS veteran or a new player, CS2 delivers a highly competitive and satisfying experience that‚Äôs hard to match.

Verdict: A promising extraction shooter with a strong identity that prioritizes tension and cooperation over pure twitch reflexes.

ARC Raiders immediately stands out through its atmosphere. The world feels hostile and oppressive in a way that supports its core loop‚Äîevery decision carries risk, and survival is never guaranteed. The sound design plays a huge role here; distant machine noises and environmental audio constantly keep players on edge.

Gameplay leans more toward deliberate pacing than frantic action. Combat rewards positioning, awareness, and team coordination rather than reckless aggression. Encounters with AI enemies feel purposeful, and resource management creates real tension during longer runs.

Visually, the game establishes a clear aesthetic without overcomplicating the presentation. Environments are readable, enemy silhouettes are distinct, and performance during testing felt stable given the scale of encounters.

As with most playtest builds, content depth is currently limited. Progression systems show potential, but it‚Äôs too early to judge long-term retention. Some mechanics would benefit from clearer feedback, especially during high-pressure situations.

What Works Well

Strong atmosphere and audio design

Tension-driven extraction gameplay

Encourages teamwork and planning

Clear visual readability

What Needs Improvement

Long-term progression depth remains uncertain

Some systems need clearer player feedback

Balance tuning will be critical as content expands

Final Thoughts:
ARC Raiders has a solid foundation and a distinct voice within the extraction shooter space. If progression, balance, and content variety continue to evolve, this could become a standout title rather than just another genre entry.

The game at its core is great. However, there are a few things truly holding it back. Embark is very slow to balance, patch and release content. So slow that most of the time they are completely behind the curve with exploits, hacking, and gun balance. The game could be so much better if the dev team were more proactive and focused on community feedback. Hopefully they figure this out sooner rather than later.

Major issues: Weapon balancing. High end guns are basically pointless
Hackers and exploiters: The game has been out with game breaking exploits for months that still haven't been compeltely addressed.
Content: Map conditions are lacking, decks/cosmetics all need to be tweaked and refreshed at higher intervals. Trials are completely broken. Solo's should not be ranked with Trio's and most of the trials themselves are obnoxious with poor end of season rewards.

I‚Äôm leaving this review so others don‚Äôt end up in the same situation I did.

I picked up ARC Raiders under the impression that PvP was optional or avoidable. After spending 40 hours in the game, it‚Äôs clear that PvP is mandatory and deeply baked into progression. Avoiding other players is not realistic if you want to advance.

If you‚Äôre looking for a primarily PvE experience or something where PvP is truly optional, be aware: this is a PvPvE extraction shooter, and player combat is unavoidable.

The game itself may be fine if that‚Äôs what you want‚Äîbut it was not what I expected going in.

Arc Raiders has a serious cheating problem. Roughly 10 hours in, it became clear something was off. After encountering blatant cheaters, I can personally confirm they exist‚ÄîI know people who use cheats in-game. When enforcement amounts to temporary bans, competitive integrity is nonexistent. Hard to recommend in this state.

You have to rely on ratting or playing like a shriveled shrimp if you want to get anything done. I have not run into a single lobby of friendly players yet and I cannot say it will happen anytime soon. The customization for your character in this game is also buns doo doo butt. Fun with friends and fun solo. The matchmaking algorithm is somewhat cheesable in that you can easily get peaceful, friendly matches by loading in to a handful and either extracting or dying while having done no damage to other players (not even on accident!). Other things that may help achieve this is having your character call out "don't shoot", extracting with other players, healing/defibrillating other players, etc. To return to PVP matches simply damage another player. This cheesability is definitely a perk and provides more control to the gamer. We are all well accustomed to blackbox SBMM that seemingly has no rhyme or reason and this is a refreshing (and hopefully intentional) implementation by the devs.

Other than that, it has flavors of Rust, Borderlands, HELLDIVERS, Tarkov, and a sprinkle of Fortnite; however, it still very much has it's own identity. It seems there is a tasteful undertone of old Soviet aesthetics woven into all the core/base graphics/designs. It's just a great game and a great value--don't wait for it to go on sale if you are still on the fence.

Arc Raiders absolutely nails the sweet spot between tense survival gameplay and cinematic sci-fi vibes. The world feels alive and dangerous, with every run delivering those heart-pounding ‚Äúdo we push our luck or extract now?‚Äù moments. Combat is punchy and satisfying, enemy design is genuinely intimidating, and the atmosphere does a ton of heavy lifting ‚Äî eerie, beautiful, and constantly keeping you on edge.

What really stands out is how rewarding teamwork feels without punishing solo players. The progression is meaningful, the risk-vs-reward loop is addictive, and every encounter feels like it matters. Add in slick visuals, tight sound design, and a strong identity that sets it apart from other extraction shooters, and you‚Äôve got something special.

If you‚Äôre into high-stakes gameplay, smart design, and a world that pulls you in and refuses to let go, Arc Raiders is a must-play. Easily five stars. üöÄüëæ

MWZ was PVE and it worked great! Making this game PVE with PVP events would solve a lot of its problems.

It's a great game at it's core, and I get the tension, suspense, risk and reward, but sadly what ruins the experience is the other side of humanity. The gamers that shoot on sight, the extract campers, the ones that scream "dont shoot!" then the minute they get close, mow you down, those who play solely for the purpose of ruining the experience for others. We call these players, RATs.

It changes you, it's a toxic cycle.
You start off friendly and enjoy interactions with other raiders, working together to keep each other safe from Arc, a super helpful community who even drop items at your feet, then after a while you get mowed down by one of the aforemented rats, and again, and then again, and again, and again. Then you start playing cautiously, you're suspicious, you no longer trust human intent, and when players don't respond to your greetings, you default to concluding they're hostile, and so YOU engage first, you mow them down, you slowly become, the RAT.

Then every interaction from there on out, you become what you hated, and you become responsible for ruining everyone elses experience.

Embark have done their best with aggression-based-matchmaking, but the key flaw is that it does not decipher player intent - and how could it without reading your thoughts? If you attack someone in self defense, the system still considers that you engaged in PvP and then matches you with more lobbys of players inclined towards PvP - the opposite of your intent.  I don't know what the answer is, but after a while it gets tiring, and the fun, stops.

That's just the solo cycle. Duo's and Trio's are almost 100% PvP. If you want to chill with friends and take down some Arc - forget it, Arc Raiders with friends does not accomodate for that.

Then there's the streamers, 100% PvP gameplay, influencing others into adopting the same play style.  I'm not sure what's worse, the streamers who influence players, or the sheep who are so easily influenced because they don't have a single thought for themselves.

Yes, PvP can be fun, but if Arc raiders is to have any longevity, it must accomodate all audiences - it needs to be a choice.

I implore you to heed my words and DO NOT buy this game, if you want to enjoy the game please play on a console. Firstly, I am good at the game, not a PRO but still actually put effort into learning game mechanics and trying to better myself and have done so since FIFA 13 UT.

1. Cheaters. This game is FILLED to the brim with cheaters and you might think I am exaggerating / tilted but I promise you, its really THAT bad. It's extremely common in high divisions / champs to have 10+ of your 15 games be either the click script hack (changing slider values to make you slow etc, you'll hear an audible GUI sound when they do it), people using AI to play for them, console players using a Cronus Zen (script cheats), controllers being forcefully disconnected and finally if you're (un)lucky cheaters that replace your ENTIRE team with fake players that cannot be switched to / moved. Oh yeah, did I also mention that cheaters can also fake / spoof being a console to get around users that have crossplay disabled, also for more context I peaked at mid division 3 and played champs and this was my average experience for about the month and a half I played. (I literally couldn't get any higher due to cheaters every game)
EDIT: Forgot to mention that the game has an INVASIVE kernal-level anti cheat that clearly just is false advertising / just doesn't actually exist.

2. The PC version of FC26 is TERRIBLE. Yes, somehow the game being terribly optimized is only the second biggest thing wrong with the game. I cannot speak for mid / entry level PCS but FPS wise my high end PC actually got acceptable FPS without any upscalers and graphics wise it actually looks pretty good on max settings. BUT, and this is a big but, if you want to play ONLINE in friendlies, rivals, champs, clubs etc you have to turn all of your settings to LOW and cap your FPS to either 60 / 120 fps (sigh) or somehow you'll have an extra 3-5ms of input lag on everything you do, for whatever reason this only applies to online modes and works perfectly fine in anything thats offline (squad battles, manager / career mode etc). If you look up input lag FC26 PC you'll find 100's of posts on EA's own forums talking about this exact issue and begging EA to fix it since its been in the game since launch, but alas its still a major problem. (The only things that help are what I said above^)
EDIT: if you also have an Nvidia GPU you need to roll-back to minimum ver. 566.36 any latest driver version will also cause high input lag somehow? The game also has crashing issues if you play uncapped FPS. 

3. Gameplay. Playstyles "in theory" sound like a really cool addition making in-game players more akin to their IRL counterparts with each players unique style and philosophy on how they approach the game, but being classic EA some of the styles are so OVERPOWERED its unreal and have not / WILL not ever be nerfed until the next game comes along. Anticipate+, Finesse+, Low driven+, pinged pass+ tiki taka+ etc... are so strong that actual stats on cards seem to be an afterthought when trying to create meta teams now. AI defending is WAY too strong that people will not even switch too defenders anymore and will just run back with a midfielder because the AI is guaranteed to turn into prime Maldini and block / intercept ANYTHING. (They did a patch recently attempting to nerf it but its still just as OP.) Dear EA Support Team,

I am writing to request a refund for EA Sports FC 26, as the game is not playable in normal match conditions on my system.

During standard matches (e.g. league or competitive fixtures), gameplay consistently drops into extreme slow motion, rendering matches effectively unplayable. This issue does not occur in youth matches, menus, or other areas of the game, and my system otherwise runs games and applications normally. The problem is therefore isolated to core match gameplay in EA Sports FC 26.

I have attempted standard troubleshooting steps, but the issue persists and fundamentally prevents normal play. As a football game, real-time match performance is a core and essential function; when this does not operate correctly, the product fails in its primary purpose.

Under the Consumer Rights Act 2015, digital content must be:

Of satisfactory quality

Fit for purpose

As described

In its current state, EA Sports FC 26 does not meet these requirements. A product that cannot run standard matches at normal speed cannot reasonably be considered fit for purpose, regardless of whether limited modes function correctly.

As the fault materially affects gameplay and cannot be resolved through reasonable user action, I believe I am entitled to a refund under UK consumer law. I am therefore requesting a refund for this purchase.

Please advise if you require any additional information, system details, or diagnostic output to progress this request.

Kind regards,

O Geometry Dash, thou trial of flashing light and cruel design,
Where cubes do leap and spires do bite with merciless delight.
Each beat a heartbeat of the soul, each spike a sharpened doubt,
Yet still the player presses on, though failure shouts aloud.

For in thy realm, no victory comes to those who fear the fall.
A thousand deaths must school the hand before one stands up tall.
Mistakes are writ in crimson sparks, but lessons burn in gold,
And patience turns the trembling novice into spirits bold.

What art thou, Dash, but life made pure
A single path, no turning back?
The rhythm guides, the eyes must trust,
The mind must hold where hands may crack.

Press on, brave heart, when progress seems a lie,
When one more spike denies the dream you seek.
For triumph lives not in the flawless try,
But in the will that rises, weak yet speaks:

‚ÄúOnce more.‚Äù

And so thou jump‚Äôst again, refined by every loss,
Till chaos bends to mastery and fear is but a ghost.
At last the final portal fades, the level stands complete
Not just the game is conquered then, but doubt beneath thy feet.

Remember this, when worlds beyond the screen feel just as steep:
No spike eternal stands before a soul that dares to leap.

[h1]There‚Äôs not much to say here: BG3 hits hard. [/h1]

The replayability is basically [b]infinite[/b], because everything changes based on how you play. I wanted my save to line up with how I played Baldur‚Äôs Gate 1 and 2, so my first playthrough was absolutely packed with mods‚Äîpurely to accommodate personal details and role-play choices.

And this is where Larian deserves massive credit. The level of support they give to the modding community is insane. Mods help smooth out small issues, improve quality of life, and massively boost immersion. Whether you‚Äôre a long-time fan doing deep roleplay (me) or a newcomer trying to survive your first D&D dice roll, the options are there.

You can feel the care Larian has, not just for the game, but for the community around it. I absolutely recommend playing and exploring everything it has to offer‚Äîand yes, I do recommend the modded experience.

That said, since this game is deeply rooted in tabletop D&D, some mechanics can feel rough if you‚Äôre new. Vanilla is totally viable, but if you go that route, just know: it will not be easy.

I‚Äôll probably do a no-mod run later for achievements, but honestly? Even without a single achievement, being able to live this story the way it was envisioned and expanded by the community is incredible enough to me.

[b]BG3 is easily a top 4 game of my life.[/b]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Pros[/h2]
[b]+[/b] Near-infinite replayability
[b]+[/b] Choices actually matter (a lot)
[b]+[/b] Incredible writing, characters, and worldbuilding
[b]+[/b] Outstanding mod support
[b]+[/b] You can feel the passion behind the project

[h2]Cons[/h2]
[b]-[/b] Steep learning curve for newcomers
[b]-[/b] D&D mechanics can be overwhelming at first
[b]-[/b] Vanilla can feel unforgiving if you don‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre doing

My first playthrough gave me ~200 hours, and I'm sure I'll play this game at least 2 more times as the base game is highly replayable given the sheer number of hidden and missable or locked encounters, variety of dialogue choices and paths, races, multiple endings, and classes or combat style. The game is also extremely moddable and actually encouraged as there is an in-game mod manager natively built in that is very simple and easy to use with thousands of community made mods
One of the top 5 games of all time.

I have never played anything like this before and not really into DnD. The closest game I can think of is Fire Emblem: Three Houses but this blows that completely out of the water. I love that character interaction/talking is just as important as combat, and how you literally have to roll for everything, making it feel like there is always uncertainty... just like in real life. Very immersive and fun, I regret neglecting this game for so long.

Baldur's Gate III is the most D&D fun you can have on your own. The combat is a blast to play through (and abuse in some situations) and the inter-character drama makes the game worth playing. It's helpful to have reddit and the wiki with you as you play, but there is nothing you can't do with enough reloading to a previous save point. 5/5 will play again.

My opinion, it's the most compelling game I can hope to play. Some of the inventory can add unnecessarily to what is already a long game. It's already difficult to get through the game unless you have occasional chunk of time to sit and play it, advancing the story and managing your party. But when I do play it I never regret it!

I was excited to play this game, considering all the hype and praise. Unfortunatley, while very expansive, the game is limited by the very strict DnD ruleset, that ends up making the game combat dull, and too much of the game progress reliant on chance rolls of the dice (skill checks).

Combat makes up alot of the game, but due to the strict adherence to the DnD ruleset, you end up being very limited in the choice of spells available for magic casters. The most powerful spells require "concentration", which means throughout the game your spell casters will cast just one powerful spell, and then hide from enemies so as to not have their "concentration" broken.

The abundance of locks that block the progress of the game means that in every playthrough, the player is forced to include a thief character in their party. Such characters are very weak combat-wise and do not pull their weight.

One of the joys of adventure games is supposed to be the upgrade in armour and weapons as one progresses. The game provides very little scope in that regard. My characters all had the same gear from level 7 up until the level cap of 12.

The crafting mechanic is so simple and primitive, it could have been left out of the game entirely without affecting the quality of gameplay.

The maps are poorly designed. 40% of the areas of the maps displayed in each act are impossible to explore or access. In act 2 it is very easy to complete one sequence of quests earlier than the developers intended, and by doing so, the game will eliminate a major hub and quest lines from the game entirely. This is very poor design.

This will be the last time I purchase a game based on the DnD ruleset.
worth every penny if you love rich story and turn based combat.

I adore this game. Though it has its quirks and the pacing of Act III is odd in comparison to the two preceding acts, the depth of the story, gorgeous level design, and the performances make this game second to none. 

Ongoing hotfixes even years after release and prompt responses to bug reports are much appreciated. As a completionist, I love to poke around all corners of the map and am consistently rewarded for my curiosity with story tidbits, references to previous installments and connections to other 5e lore. I have also been rewarded with some bugs that the vast majority of players probably wouldn't deal with. The dev team has responded to every bug report and let me know whether or not the bug was known etc.

Have I *technically* beat the game yet, even after 250 hours of play? No... Still, I have loved just about every minute I've spent playing this game, and my hesitance to finish my first playthrough is because of just that. The replay value is incredible, with a unique experience and countless lines for different races, classes, backgrounds, and genuine sense of consequence. I find myself procrastinating finishing my first playthrough out of sentimentality and curiosity for just how different another playthrough could be. 

Even after watching let's play content and tutorials for difficult fights, I regularly stumble on tiny details I've never seen before. Official mod support adds even more to this! I can see myself playing this game for at least another 250 hours easily.

TL;DR: It's probably the greatest RPG video game of all time and the greatest fantasy adventure I've ever experienced outside of film and books. Take the passion, vision and skill of 90's and early 2000's developers, give them modern tools and BG3 is what you get.

--------------------------------------------

Easily the deepest RPG I've personally ever played and at a time when it is most needed in the industry. If you think you can do it, there's a good chance you probably can. You are REWARDED for thinking outside the box. They've designed and voiced so many random things that very few people will ever see in their run. The sheer amount of choice you have and how much it impacts your story is just amazing. And you're not burdened with silly weight or inventory limits because they're incredibly generous with carry weight, quantity is infinite AND you can send things right to camp (infinite storage) if you can't carry it. Basically everything I've ever wanted. 

You can place items inside of containers while they're in your inventory - say, a body inside a barrel - then throw that barrel and it will break open and the body and everything else will spill out. Fill it to the brim with explosives and throw it on some fire (or throw fire on it) and BOOOOOM! Make a nuke with your entire stash if you feel like it. There's just no reason to do that and yet they did it. You can push and throw people off cliffs, into lava, etc. You can make people drop their weapons, steal them, enchant them with spells, throw them away or at someone else and so on. You can shut doors on people and put magical locks on them to divide and conquer groups of enemies. Instead of drinking them, you can throw potions AT people or at the ground and run through them to get the effect. You have SO MANY COOL OPTIONS and you'd be surprised how useful they are in a pinch.

This game has secrets within secrets and you may never find them and that's GOOD because it has insane replayability. The fact that you can freely kill off important characters that have extensive roles in this game is just mind-boggling. And you'd never know how extensive. You're tasked with killing someone but you choose to knock them out instead? They might just come back later. No hand-holding here either. You must REMEMBER that you can do these things. It's all your intuition. It truly is your choice that matters. 

Visually, the game is absolutely stunning and detailed. No aliasing whatsoever either. Beautiful, crisp and clear in 4K with FSR 4 via OptiScaler. Far clearer than when it originally released. Shadows dance on the walls when you light your torches and they will POP in HDR. Gorgeous, colorful fantasy environments you can tell they put a ton of thought into designing. The smallest items are often detailed and intricate. And you can display them at camp if you wish, placing them wherever you want (just be careful, it will all go into your stash once you change Acts!). Speaking of camp, camp often if for no other reason than to see how many camp environments they designed! That attention to detail is what separates Larian from the rest.

The voice acting is incredible, the NPC models are awesome looking and facial expressions/motion capture is fantastic. The sound design and music are both amazing and epic. Great photo mode as well with lots of options.

Gear is unique and interesting and it's actually useful to keep gear in your bag so you can buff up and swap it out for different situations or when you run out of charges to use on the item. It makes finding new items exciting and cool. 

Fast travel times are insane. 3 seconds to go from one area to another within the same Act and 10 to 15 seconds between Acts.

I've only just finished Act 1 at the time of this review, 127 hours in. You may not spend this much time in Act 1 but I've spent entire afternoons replaying a single situation just to see how many ways I could do it and how creative I could get in my attempt to break the game. I scoured every corner in this game to find everything I could. And when I'm finished, I'll probably do it all over again with different followers and a different class, making different choices.

I know people say that Act 1 is the best and most fleshed out Act but I've already gotten my money's worth. It'd be a shame if the quality dropped off a cliff but either way, given enough time and passion for a project, Larian has already proven that they are in the business of making MASTERPIECES.

As far as I'm concerned, they are the new GOAT in the RPG game and I will be there will bells on when Divinity releases.

I don't know why all these new ARPGs feel like they're obligated to turn the genre into clunky, overdesigned single player MOBAs.

The lag isn't helping.

POE 1 is probably still the best ARPG ever made to this day. With over 10 years of free content, and endless customization, once you try it it's hard to really get hooked on another game of the genre.

POE 2 is on the track to become the next best one. The graphics are gorgeous for game like this (the trailers are not lying to you, it's actually what you'll see in game), the world design, the fact that you can move with AWSD and aim with the mouse. You still have a lot of options, but it has been streamlined and is easier for new players in my opinion. It's hard to screw up a build, unlike in POE1. The respec has been made way easier, it's only a bit of gold to pay instead of finding specific orbs. 
Is it as deep as POE1 ? Obviously not, it lacks dev time. But seeing their economic model, that has been working forever, the game is not going anywhere. With a new league, and new content every 3 months (you can see this like a free DLC), it is hands down the game that will give you the most bang for your buck, ever. 
(You do have to pay for early access, but once the game release it'll be F2P just like POE1)

Excellent fundamentals but flawed in some finer details.  Path of Exile 2 is an absolutely fantastic ARPG, following in the footsteps of its first incarnation and delivering complexity, stunnign visuals and of course that ever so frustrating excess loot decisions making we all love of these games.

That being said, this game is not for everyone, and I really do mean this.  PoE2 is not an easy game, you aren't going to one-shot bosses and sail through content.  You aren't going to be able to collect all those shiny items that drop (at least not easily).  But by far and away the most frustrating things are:

a) Lack of resources - as a new player, you will struggle with gold, you will struggle for items, you will struggle for upgrades and customisation options.  That adds a little to the joy of actually getting somethign cool, but it can be a massive grind at times, leaving you feel rather underpowered and worried about actually spendign anythign you DO get given its rarity.

and

b) Boss fights that just aren't fun.  The boss fights go on, for a while.  More so than most other ARPGs I've played.  This in and of itself isn't a bad thing... if it was a case of gearing up, learning the fight mechanics etc, but sadly there is often just too much health, too many random things shooting all over the screen and no real easy way around it.  It doesn't make for compelling gameplay, just frustration.

The builds can feel overwhelming, they've tried to give you maximum flexibility, and I like that but do yourself a favour... make sure you find a good one for that first run through or you will probably quit with a smashed keyboard.  

Well worth a go, but infinitely frustrating that I feel a lot of players won't appreciate the difficulty and frustration as a good thing.  This isn't a dark-souls game, the creators need to find a way to balance difficulty with progression... and quicker than they are right now.  A stunning game let down by a huge learnign curve and outright gear level caps far too often in just the campaign does not make for an exciting or appealing game for the masses.  Keep the difficult progression to end-game and you will have a far happier playbase.

I‚Äôm extremely picky when it comes to games. So picky that I‚Äôve quit during tutorials more times than I can count. It usually doesn‚Äôt take long for me to decide whether something clicks or not. But when a friend introduced me to Dead by Daylight, that changed fast.

What hooked me was how deceptively simple the game feels at first, while hiding a surprising amount of depth underneath. The core concept is easy to grasp, but mastering it is a completely different story. Now, after more than 700 hours of gameplay, I finally feel qualified to leave a review.

At the end of a long workday, once I‚Äôm home and settled, my first instinct is to boot up Dead by Daylight and run a few matches. That‚Äôs how deeply this game has worked its way into my routine‚Äîand honestly, I‚Äôm perfectly fine with that. It‚Äôs become my go-to way to unwind, challenge myself, and keep coming back for ‚Äújust one more match.‚Äù

Started playing Killer because why not? I had zero clue what I was doing just placing traps, getting stunned, and watching survivors teabagging me. I wasn't even mad, just confused. I was basically just button-mashing at that point.

After the match, the end-game chat was a mess. They were speaking Chinese, and when I translated it, they told me to uninstall. Super toxic. Over time, I started to learn the ropes, though I still don't care about 'tunneling' or 'camping' if a survivor is in front of me, I chase. Simple as that. After 90 hours, I‚Äôd say 30% of my matches are pure toxicity, which makes it a nightmare to learn new killers.

My Survivor experience is even worse. I can't loop to save my life and I've probably landed less than 10 pallet stuns in my entire career. But I never teabag, because I know exactly how it feels from my first games as Killer.

Playing Killer is actually fun, but survivors complain and get salty for no reason. This game is literally the Twitter of gaming. Do I keep playing? Yes. Am I annoyed? Also yes.

I don't leave reviews for games but given how much I've enjoyed BF6 combined with the negativity It's receiving from the """fan"""base and the """community""" or God forbid..."""Battlefield VETERANS"""...fucking cringe. I've decided to leave something behind of my own, both because it's cathartic and for my own peace of mind.

BF6 is easily the best Battlefield experience I've had to date, a close second is BFV. It's not meant to be realistic and it's not meant to be as arcade-y as Call of Duty either, It fills a niche somewhere between arcade gameplay and mil-sim (not that it even gets close to mil-sim territory mind you, and that's by design.) and it does a fantastic job of it. 

What this does is give players the freedom of pulling off batshit insane flanks where you kill 3 squads from behind or otherwise very fun and stupid things (jihad jeep) while still being surrounded by a very authentic large scale war atmosphere.
What it does for the developers is give them the freedom of creating sandboxes that don't have to be tied down by 100% realism and where they can prioritize "balls to the walls" action over running/driving 20km to an objective and getting sniped/RPGd and having to do it al over again.

(and if you're going to say that Battlefield isn't about "ballls to the walls" action, I'm going to call you a hypocrite because I know you enjoyed Metro as much as the rest of us, so don't even start.
"Yeah but that's not ALL Battlefield is abou-- "
No, it isn't. And BF6 offers a lot more than just a "Metro-like" experience, despite what Reddit would like you to believe.)

On top of the atmosphere of the game being on par if not better than that of BF3, the game also runs incredibly well. By no means do I have a beefy PC, I run a Ryzen 5 5500 and an RX 6650XT w/ 16gb DDR4 with Digital Foundry's PS5 Performance equivalent settings at 1080p with FSR at Quality (Because FSR at Quality looks better than the native 1080p TAA implementation), and it *never* drops below 60fps (it used to a little bit when the game first launched but that has seemingly been fixed since.)

The audio design is bar none the best the industry has to offer right now. If you have access to a surround sound capable audio setup then this game will show you why you spent so much money on a surround sound capable audio setup.

The gameplay is incredibly smooth, the days of BF3 and BF4's janky ass horrible movement is over (it was well over by BFV, but that's a different conversation.) Transitions from pretty much any stance to sprint is as responsive as you would ever need it to be, and the transition from any stance to falling on the floor sideways like Emily Blunt in the intro to Sicario feels as cool as you would expect.

All that being said, I want to say this outright: This isn't the Battlefield you remember. Because the Battlefield *you* remember is marred by your yearning for a simpler time when you didn't need to pay taxes (or as much as you do now) and you didn't have kids you didn't realized you didn't want until after you had them and the world was in a slightly better shape, and your parents were still together etc etc. The Battlefield *you* remember likely isn't even what most people remember because nobody remembers the same fucking Battlefield, because while your 420696 hours might have been spent on a single hardcore server filled with only (and I do mean ONLY) your favorite maps (because lets forget those maps you *didn't* like for the sake of your nostalgia) somebody else's 7 quintillion hours (let's not forget they're a VETERAN after all...fucking cringe.) could have been spent just playing on the normal ttk, normal map rotation DICE official servers. So of course this isn't the same Battlefield you remember, because the Battlefield you remember doesn't even exist in the first place, and it would have been impossible for the developers to cater to both the VETERANS...fucking cringe. And new players who want more interesting mechanics from their modern FPSs. And that's not even accounting for the fact that no two VETERANS...fucking cringe. Can agree on what made Battlefield a good game to begin with, because it's just an illusion, it's just them being sky-high on their own nostalgia trips of their own subjective experiences. There's no way DICE could have incorporated your Battlefield experience into the game for everyone and everyone just unanimously decides that what they decided to incorporate was objectively the right choice.

"Hey you remember that cool-blue tinge BF3 had to it? Yeah They added it to BF6! The callback is kinda coo--"
"Yeah I fucking hate that disgusting filter, just gimme my clarity!"
"Oh...I kinda liked it."

This ^ isn't a strawman by the way, this debate actually happened close to launch, accompanied with a Youtube video I *know* you watched called "Why Does Battlefield 6 look Like that?*(De-Graded)"

And finally..."but what about the *FEMALES* on the frontlines!!!1!?? There are no *FEMALES* on the frontlines in *REAL WAR*" (not that you would know what real war feels like because you're just a civilian with no time served in the armed forces who gets off on calling himself a battlefield veteran because he gets to feel like all that time he secretly feels is wasted playing video games is suddenly worth something after all (it isn't) but anyway.) Grow up. This is a fictional universe where you can get blown to proverbial bits by a tank and get revived by funny looking paddles, this game isn't, and never was realistic and nor should it be.

"But I don't like hearing *FEMALES* screaming when they get shot or burned!" 
-He says with a straight face, ignoring his 7tb folder of questionably aged anime girls getting fucked by anything but a human penis.

Again, grow up. I'm sure none of the women you've ever met in your life could give a fuck whether you don't like hearing women screaming in a war video game, nobody is impressed, sit down little man, your chicken nuggies will be with you shortly.

Anyway, this game is fantastic. Buy it you're interested, you won't regret it. 
This is the last time I even so much as look at the "community" side of this franchise because these people are pathetic.

Cheers

First off, this game is genuinely insane. For me it‚Äôs straight out of a dream. The scale, the chaos, mad stuff.  Was it a ‚Äúbillion-dollar game‚Äù? No. A lot of that number is marketing. The price is‚Ä¶ debatable. I treat it more like take my money and build with it. As well as, it feels less like the publisher being greedy and more like the new normal for game pricing in this economy. 

That said, there are clear issues. The netcode is not great (often die behind walls and too fast), and some maps feel too small to let vehicles really breathe. A lot of meat grinding at times. Weapon variety is also weirdly limited right now ‚Äî too many guns feel same-y, and secondaries especially are thin (it‚Äôs basically two real choices at the moment). I like the idea of fast 20 gun lvls and I don't think it should be any easier. 

But here‚Äôs the important part: the foundation is strong. The gunplay feels satisfying, the core loop is addictive, and when the game hits its peak, it‚Äôs unreal. Now, it actually feels like the devs are listening ‚Äî the Season 2 direction looks promising, and if they keep at it and improving balance. this could easily become an absolute banger.

Was drawn to BF6 by the promise of the franchise returning to its grounded modern shooter roots. 
I played the open beta and aside from some lag, de-sync and hit-reg issues the beta was super fun and really brought me back to how I felt playing BF4 and BF1. 
I was high on hopium and ignored all the people saying not to prepurchace.

While at first BF6 was a breath of fresh air basic gameplay is solid (aside from some rather annoying player movement) I quickly lost interest.

Weapons:

Weapon progression and unlocks were a tedious grindfest, (like the PSR 200 headshots from over 200 meters away challenge) and while the devs did their best to address some of the outrageous challenges weapon progression is still currently an extremely grind ridden affair.
Several weapons (in my opinion) have not had their attachments properly balanced in terms cost and effectiveness. For instance, the M277 carbine completely decked out with expensive attachments will still, without fail have worse control, fire rate, accuracy, ads, mag capacity. and muzzle velocity than an unmodified M4. Now this would be fine if these weapons didn't share the same DPS value despite the M277 firing a much stronger cartridge. 
If the M277 had worse control and mag capacity in exchange for better muzzle velocity and superior DPS it wouldn‚Äôt be an issue in my book. Spicier round = worse control/higher damage. However, because the M277 only does the same 25 DPS as the M4 but has so many drawbacks there is no reason to use it. Now that‚Äôs a rant about only one gun but, the point is there are several weapons in the sandbox that have similar issues, I simply think the M277 it's one of the worst cases.

Challenges:

Several challenges for XP, Battlepass progression points, and cosmetics don‚Äôt consider factors which affect the players ability to complete the challenge. For instance, my weekly challenges were constantly filled with Red Sec tied objectives even though I never installed it and don‚Äôt intend to. 

Some challenges related to even base game modes are impossible to attempt because as the mode is either dead or broken. Game lobbies often never fully populate and in some modes (like in all my attempts to play KOTH) they fail to populate with bots so the match simply never starts, making it sometimes impossible to complete:  "play this mode X times" challenges.

A more pressing issue concerning challenges relates to the paid battlepass.
The total number of points needed to complete the battlepasses is unreachable depending on what challenges the game randomly generates for you. Some people despite having completed every challenge possible were unable to unlock the items they bought because of this. (I think DICE gave them the items they missed out on in the mail but an issue like that shouldn‚Äôt have existed in the first place.)

Tech issues:

The hit reg and lag has never been fully fixed since the Beta, (and to my experience persists even now) I still often run into desync, hit reg, lag, and other networking/ server issues. 
As mentioned above certain game modes seem literally unplayable because of several issues concerning the match making. 
the game has often disconected me for 'inactivity' while im in the middle of an active firefight in breakthrough or conquest.

cosmetics/store/maps:

Maps:
There aren‚Äôt enough.
Many of the maps in BF6 simply pale in comparison to their counterparts in BF4 and BF1. while they're not horrible (for the most part) they're nothing outstanding either. levelution and destruction is super cool and looks absolutely awesome, it certainly outshines BF1 and BFV but, so far I‚Äôve seen nothing close to the extreme destruction possible in BF3 and BF4.

Cosmetics & store:

One of my largest annoyances with BF6 is the cosmetics.
The grounded modern aesthetic and setting we were promised by the devs was abandoned the instant the game released. Instead of the grounded modern military feel the beta had, BF6 became airsoft LARP. 
Otherwise fine Skins were ruined with massive amounts of neon and fluro colours which in no way resembled nor belonged on military uniforms and equipment.
In many cases the skins blend the aesthetics of Nato and PAX making it hard to identify your enemies and friendlies. This issue was extremely prominent with the California Resistance skins. The update introduced a new Nato squad and the several individual Pax skins which could be purchased from the store. These skins all shared the dad operator making them indistinguishable from each other.

Some of the skins look fine, most of them don‚Äôt. The issue in general It‚Äôs not a biggie for some. Some even like the skins we're getting. However, for me it was a major selling point for the game. I got fed up with COD multiplayer because of this same issue (characters and players looking ridiculously out of place) and the devs for BF6 saying that their skins and designs would be grounded and realistic was music to my ears. (I legit kinda feel scammed looking back on it)
The game sells AI generated slop in the form of patches, player emblems, weapon skins, and other cosmetics and it sells this slop for disproportionally large sums of money. In general the store prices are extremely high for the quality of goods it offers thus why I‚Äôve only ever bought a single item.

I put off giving a negative review for a long time, hoping that BF6's networking and server issues would be fixed. 
They haven't.
I hoped they would improve, progression systems, gun balance, and match making.
They haven't.
I hoped they would return to their promise of a grounded modern military shooter with grounded cosmetics.
They haven‚Äôt.

I spent my money hoping this would be the grand return of Battlefield.
it wasn‚Äôt.
if you‚Äôre looking for a polished and immersive, grounded Battlefield experience save your money.

[i] Summary for Battlefield 6‚Äôs bizarre cosmetics and content choices so far:

NATO soldiers now look like airsoft clowns dunked in day-glo paint. Bright gas masks, silly balaclavas, random face paint ‚Äî as if they‚Äôve entirely forgotten they‚Äôre meant to be in an army. DICE have simply slapped on whatever nonsense took their fancy this season. Yellow paint smeared all over mercs, or blinding white with neon green, topped off with some so-called ‚Äúcamouflage‚Äù that achieves precisely the opposite of its intended purpose. It‚Äôs the kind of visual assault that makes you wonder whether anyone in the studio has even glanced at a real soldier in the last ten years.

Ally or foe? Who can tell. Everyone‚Äôs a glowing muppet. The same clownish colour palette, the same idiotic smiley skulls, gas masks covered in graffiti, or, for a real stroke of genius, literal airsoft masks with holes cut out for the eyes. Visual clarity is completely abandoned, and with it, any sense of tactical gameplay. The result is chaos masquerading as cosmetic variety ‚Äî bright, incoherent, and entirely unnecessary.

And this is what DICE are calling ‚Äúgrounded‚Äù and ‚Äúback to the roots‚Äù? Whose roots, exactly ‚Äî Battlefield 2042‚Äôs? Right. Brilliant. Absolute muppets, clearly. A masterclass in misunderstanding what made the franchise work in the first place.

This is what a visual identity crisis looks like in full swing. No coherent style, no consistent language, no bloody clue what Battlefield is supposed to be anymore. Every season veers off in a different direction; none of it seems considered, and nothing respects the game‚Äôs own internal logic. Compare that to Battlefield 1‚Äôs first two big updates: content was delivered regularly, the art direction was disciplined, and even cosmetic additions respected the tone, setting, and, crucially, visual readability. Players could immediately understand what belonged and what didn‚Äôt. Here? Confusion is the only consistent feature.

And yet, people are expected to pay ¬£60 for this. Sixty pounds for a game that struggles to deliver grounded cosmetics, let alone content, which is drip-fed as slowly as possible.

Disappointing? That‚Äôs generous. Pathetic? Closer to the mark. Unmitigated, mindless muppetry from top to bottom. Gimmicks and chaotic design choices are all that keep it moving. And the most galling part? DICE appear entirely unconcerned. This is not bold. It is not modern. It is a farce. Absolute, unmitigated farce.

I literally just finished a grueling gaming session of some 4 hours where game put me through the purgatory and then.. hell I guess ? of loosing streak of.. I didn't count.. 10-15 games !???? AM I CRAZY ? To be 1 cog of 64 players and be placed in the 10 games in the row where my team stands absolutely no chance of winning ? Every time in the brand new game.. Am I being tested ??? lol Not a chance, it's just really bad code, and pure laziness and unintelligence in the era of almost universal intelligence ...  Not to be able to design a balanced and fun experience for the most of us ? It's sad really. Almost tragic I'd say.. I even bought a new PC just for this game, what a waste of time and money. And no, I'm not that bad. Through most of my BF days.. I was finishing conquest games in the very top of the score charts. As I grew older that started to fell off naturally, but this is something different, something rotten to the, and in the core of the game. Some 75% of the games, maybe even more, one team simply steamrolls the other.. I guess that might have something to do with the game losing it's 80% of the player base.. hmm I wonder why ? Maybe it was a toxic experience for those 80% as it was for me, on so many occasions ? Such a shame, since this game had so much potential, but I guess, that decline in everything and general quality and dev. enthusiasm above all went spiraling down even since Battlefield 1 - which was the last quality product in BF franchise. But All things move toward their end, of that you can be sure - the contemporary poet said, and tonight I've become painfully aware of that. Adios Battlefield ! We wont be seeing each other much..

DayZ is one of the best hardcore survival games ever made ‚Äî when it works. No hand-holding, real consequences, and unmatched tension. Every life becomes a story, every player encounter feels dangerous, and the survival mechanics (hunger, sickness, weather, medical system, gunplay) are deep and incredibly immersive.

The game truly shines on community Vanilla / Vanilla+ servers with active admins. That‚Äôs where DayZ feels fair, intense, and close to its original vision. Official servers, unfortunately, still struggle ‚Äî cheating on higher-pop servers is a known issue and actively hurts the experience.

There are also long-standing frustrations the community keeps calling out: inconsistent zombie AI and pathing, desync, hit registration issues, clunky character actions (especially throwing items and vaulting), vehicles behaving unpredictably, and general jank that breaks immersion in critical moments.

Despite all of this, DayZ remains special. No other game creates this level of tension, paranoia, and player-driven storytelling. The foundation is incredible ‚Äî it just desperately needs polish, bug fixes, and stronger anti-cheat support to reach its full potential.

If you want a true survival experience that doesn‚Äôt care about your comfort, DayZ is absolutely worth playing. Just know: the game is amazing ‚Äî and it could be so much better.

Starfield is a game with a thousand load screens...

I like idea where exploration happens in "known universe" and planes have limited stuff on them but the problem is that once you get there, the universe has already called it a day. You travel from planet to planet, each one a barren husk of potential, a cosmic sandbox where the main gameplay loop is mining disappointment.

Most of the quests are boring. Not ‚Äúslow burn‚Äù boring. Not ‚Äúsubtle‚Äù boring. Just boring. The kind of boring where your brain starts thinking about doing your taxes instead. Cool stuff like terrormorphs and everything else are replaced with finding "magical" artifacts that would give you magical powers...   

Your companions are worse. They are all relentlessly agreeable, morally flawless, and emotionally sterile‚Äîlike a focus group‚Äôs idea of a human being. They love when you make "good" choices. They hate when you do anything interesting. Traveling with them feels less like a space adventure and more like being supervised by LinkedIn profiles.

Skyrim was messy, weird, and passionate. Fallout 4, for all its flaws, was at least fun. You could lose yourself in those worlds. You could mod them into absolute chaos.

Starfield? Mods haven‚Äôt saved it. Maybe they can‚Äôt. The community hasn‚Äôt embraced it, and Bethesda now sells paid mods through their storefront. Even fixing the game comes with a receipt.

Lore? Diet lore. Zero calories.

In the end, Starfield doesn‚Äôt feel like a bold leap into the stars.
It feels like fast-traveling into irrelevance.

Lazy.

That's the word that kept coming up in my mind while playing. The execution is extremely lazy.

Apart from lacking obvious and much needed polish (Angara running around with Milky way weapons pretty early in the story, when it doesn't make sense for them to do so yet), and the story suffering from Woke bullshit (They're all pretty in your face, but the whiney krogan "overlord" even more so), the whole execution just feels lazy.

I didn't care for my companions. I didn't care for most people on my ship. The only companions that even got a semi proper character introduction was Cora and Peebee, and even that was brief. I didn't care to learn more about them. I cared about Miranda because she was the Cerberus cheerleader. Mordin left a mark on me because I got to know him through his clinic. Hell, even Zaeed's more memorable than half your Andromeda crew (and 99% of all other characters).

The writing is... boy oh boy. The characters feel like children. More often than not the dialogue was just irritating (especially looking at Cora). Cinematography is another major missing piece of the puzzle. I remember thinking - hell, even ME1's clinic shootout got more cinematography than most of this game.

Locations and major quests are forgettable, and that's (mostly) not the environment's fault (though don't get me wrong, environment design is rough - areas like New Tuchanka are boring mazes). A lot of areas feel uninspired, but it's the non-existent cinematography that's the major let down here.

Also - the "fetch" quests (and just general slew of boring, filler, go here go there fluff). It sucks. There's no reason apart from "I have to do as much as possible to avoid a possible bad ending". It's tiresome. It's disrespectful of your time. It's boring.

All that to say, the writing and execution's bad to the point of being immersion breaking. I lost interest in the game quite a few times while playing, having restarted it about 4 or 5 times since release to finally (try) to grind through and finish it. Adding mods are what got me the furthest through the game, and I usually wait until a 2nd playthrough to add mods. I didn't finish it, and I don't think this game will be seeing me again. I'd rather play through ME1 again.
not as good as ME 1,2,3 but still ok
There are a lot of flaws but its not a bad game.

Hi Roguefighter08 

I‚Äôm really sorry to hear that Star Wars Outlaws is not running well on your PC. I understand how frustrating it can be when you experience graphical glitches, your characters not interacting or other game assets do not load. 

Based on the issues you described, it is possible that the game is installed on an HDD. Star Wars Outlaws requires installation on an SSD, which is clearly stated in the official [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/star-wars-outlaws/connectivity-and-performance/article/system-requirements-for-star-wars-outlaws/000109505] system Requirements.[/url] Running the game on an HDD often causes exactly the type of performance problems you are facing.

If you have access to an SSD and choose to reinstall the game there, you should see a noticeable improvement in responsiveness and overall performance.

If your PC already meets these requirements and the issues continue, please take a look at our guide on [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/troubleshooting-technical-issues-on-pc/000061047]Troubleshooting technical issues on PC[/url] and complete all the steps listed there.

One important step is to disable any additional or unnecessary background applications, especially third-party overlays, communication tools, system utilities and monitoring software. These can interfere with performance.

To improve game‚Äôs general performance and responsiveness, disable "RTX Direct Lighting in the game Graphics settings.

You can also try the following steps.
[url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/reinstalling-supporting-software/000062655]Reinstall supporting software[/url] such as DirectX and the Visual C++ 2015 to 2022 Redistributable.
Reinstall [url=https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-framework] .NET Framework [/url] using the newest version available.

[url=https://help.steampowered.com/faqs/view/6AD7-820D-8BE5-E51F#:~:text=From%20your%20Steam%20Client%2C%20open,Cache%22%20button%20at%20the%20bottom]Clear Steam Cache folder[/url]
[url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/emptying-the-cache-of-ubisoft-connect-pc/000061966]Clear Ubisoft Connect PC Cache[/url]

If none of these steps resolve the problem, please generate your [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/generating-system-reports-to-help-troubleshooting/000061449]DxDiag and MsInfo[/url] system reports and contact us through our [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/contact]website[/url], [url=https://discord.com/invite/ubisoftofficial]Ubisoft Discord[/url] or [url=https://x.com/ubisoftsuppor]X or Twitter[/url]. We will be happy to investigate this further with you.

Try using a different device to create your account. If you're on a PC, switch to a different browser and ensure that no plugins, ad blockers, or pop-up blockers are active during the process.
 
Check out our browser troubleshooting steps for further assistance.
[url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/browser-troubleshooting-for-ubisoft-webpages/000062631] Browser troubleshooting for Ubisoft webpages[/url]
