reviews.developer_response:
Hi Normino 

I‚Äôm really sorry to hear that Star Wars Outlaws is not running well on your PC. I understand how frustrating it can be when you experience long loading times, graphical glitches or your character falls through textures.

Based on the issues you described, it is possible that the game is installed on an HDD. Star Wars Outlaws requires installation on an SSD, which is clearly stated in the official [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/star-wars-outlaws/connectivity-and-performance/article/system-requirements-for-star-wars-outlaws/000109505] system Requirements.[/url] Running the game on an HDD often causes exactly the type of performance problems you are facing.

If you have access to an SSD and choose to reinstall the game there, you should see a noticeable improvement in responsiveness and overall performance.

If your PC already meets these requirements and the issues continue, please take a look at our guide on [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/troubleshooting-technical-issues-on-pc/000061047]Troubleshooting technical issues on PC[/url] and complete all the steps listed there.

One important step is to disable any additional or unnecessary background applications, especially third-party overlays, communication tools, system utilities and monitoring software. These can interfere with performance.

To improve game‚Äôs general performance and responsiveness, disable "RTX Direct Lighting in the game Graphics settings.

You can also try the following steps.
[url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/reinstalling-supporting-software/000062655]Reinstall supporting software[/url] such as DirectX and the Visual C++ 2015 to 2022 Redistributable.
Reinstall [url=https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-framework] .NET Framework [/url] using the newest version available.

[url=https://help.steampowered.com/faqs/view/6AD7-820D-8BE5-E51F#:~:text=From%20your%20Steam%20Client%2C%20open,Cache%22%20button%20at%20the%20bottom]Clear Steam Cache folder[/url]
[url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/emptying-the-cache-of-ubisoft-connect-pc/000061966]Clear Ubisoft Connect PC Cache[/url]

If none of these steps resolve the problem, please generate your [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/connectivity-and-performance/article/generating-system-reports-to-help-troubleshooting/000061449]DxDiag and MsInfo[/url] system reports and contact us through our [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/contact]website[/url], [url=https://discord.com/invite/ubisoftofficial]Ubisoft Discord[/url] or [url=https://x.com/ubisoftsuppor]X or Twitter[/url]. We will be happy to investigate this further with you.

reviews.review:
I ONLY recommend the Standard Edition, while on a deep sale.

The best way I can describe this game is:  Hogwart's Legacy + Uncharted = This.

The game has a story and illusions of choice. I don't know much of anything about Star Wars, but the narrative was easy enough to follow and digest. Collectibles are not my thing, but there are numerous side missions for you if that's your jam.

Too many Ads on loading to Title.
The space dog sidekick is cool.
Awkwardly, no manual saving allowed while in Quests.
ND-5 Android was the highlight of the show.
You can skip Mini-Games while on Hardest Difficulty.
The eating scenes are 'Lord of the Rings' level of length.

What I can not figure out is why my Handgun has infinite ammo, but the rifles do not. Oh, well. Video games.

The game is so mid and bland compared to the previous ones. The main protagonist is sooo boring and the missions/world lack depth.
Also, and this is a big point for me, why  only female protagonist? We should have been given the option to pick the gender for the protagonist like in CyberPunk 2077.
Only good thing I can say about the game is that bought it on sale.

Shortened review, Hit me up on socials if you want to see the full thing.

Quick thing with how I review stuff. I don‚Äôt hark on the story too much as I‚Äôm a general proponent of ‚Äúskip the story, play the game‚Äù. I‚Äôm an open world sandbox veteran so I can deal with bad writing, acting, or script as long as the gameplay can hold itself up. This is why the bad lip syncing doesn‚Äôt bother me as much as it may others, because I only have to deal with it for short cutscenes before the game just gives control back to me and we move on. As such, you‚Äôre an up and comer smuggler that messes up a couple of times in short order, angering a well connected syndicate that puts a half-million bounty on you after stealing his one of a kind ship. Not a prototype this time, just a sort of ‚Äúlast surviving‚Äù type ship as it was too expensive to mass produce. So we‚Äôre let off into the world to make some friends and allies, while Kay Vess learns a very common lesson in the media; You can‚Äôt do everything alone. Something she probably should have learned nearly immediately when she almost torpedoes an entire mission when she points a gun at her client in the middle of an imperial base. Girl, can you at least wait until we‚Äôre outside?

The story here is serviceable, though it clearly wishes our protagonist Kay Vess was just Han Solo. Not every in-universe smuggler needs to be a Solo analog, but here we are. I will say it gets dangerously close to being as annoying as the protagonist from Forspoken, in that she won't shut the farrik up about nothing... But she hasn't quite crossed that line. There's moments very early on when she calls her contact a couple times to say almost nothing, something like "I've made it to the wall of the compound", I forget the exact words. It was a few days and 30 hours of gameplay ago. Absolutely worthless as an exchange, but it evens out later where a lot of her quips are to her helper pet Nix which tend to be more acceptable in context. In similar games like Horizon it makes more sense when Aloy is self-narrating as she grew up very lonely but I'm sure we all grew tired of hearing "Looks like a cave..." as we're driving by to some other objective. Vess does not do this. I‚Äôve also been informed that this has some practical use; the game relies heavily on autosaves. So when you save, exit, or crash to desktop‚Ä¶ Loading back in mid-mission may treat you with one of these nothingburgers of dialog to help remind you of what your task is.

The gameplay is familiar. It‚Äôs a Ubisoft game, so that means it‚Äôs one of two things. Creed or Cry? This is on the Creed scale as you sneak around in bushes or ventilation smoke, knock out helmeted stormtroopers, and find vent shafts as alternative routes into large bases and complexes. With us we have Nix, a little furry critter that just functions as our cellphone or drone from Watch Dogs as it helps pickpocket guards, pushes buttons, distracts and even attacks enemies in what is basically a stun/crowd control move. I love him a lot. At a certain point he gets kidnapped for a mission and I had to resist just going John Wick on everyone because I was dealing with tougher guards that couldn‚Äôt just be tapped down.

This game doesn't so much throw you map icons ad nauseum, though I am finding myself a little overwhelmed with quest entries. I find it difficult to discern which are the most important and relevant. My whole quest log is absolutely filled to the brim with this kind of stuff, none of them really tell you what the reward is (only the contracts do that) so it's difficult to discern which to focus on and what's just flavor. At some point on a day off work I kind of want to just clear my entire log that isn't my main quest... at least as my tools allow. I keep running into objectives that require tools I don‚Äôt have yet, like being able to drive over bodies of water. I wish the game made this a bit more obvious before I spent twenty minutes circling a mountain before googling the objective name and learning I needed some kind of cutter tool I won‚Äôt get until later in the story.

The game is absolutely gorgeous. It reminds me of Cyberpunk, with how lighting fixtures will pierce through the fog and weather. Every now and then I‚Äôll be driving or walking and just be struck by a stunning vista where I need to stop and enter photo mode. Alas I can‚Äôt put images in Steam reviews so if you‚Äôre seeing this on my other socials, some of my favorites will be littered throughout this review. (On Steam you can likely just jump to my profile). I was particularly impressed with how realistic the walkways in Kijimi were. Seeing the snow clumped around the walkways is very much how it behaves in real life as people walk through or kick some off to the side. I‚Äôve almost taken a screenshot of the literal ground once because I was so impressed with the melted snow clumping.

The upgrades to your speederbike are too few and far between. Since my first impressions post I‚Äôve upgraded it a couple more times and it doesn‚Äôt stop the vehicle from being heavily unresponsive. Turning barely actually turns but if I hold the turning key down a second longer than the game wants me to, I just make a hard left into a rock and that will send Vess flying and losing a health bar. There‚Äôs a mission where you have to keep pace with a teammate as you escape some imperials and I had to restart it about seven times because she‚Äôd fly off into the distance while I struggled with running into rocks, walls, and even enemy speederbikes and I couldn‚Äôt nitro boost back to her quick enough because she just -leaves-. Maddening. I hate it.

The stealth gameplay is variable. At certain times the stealth will fail through somewhat inconsistent rules. When infiltrating a large imperial base the game is nice enough to just let me shoot up one room and then I can proceed as normal. However, other times‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs a phrase that Yahtzee coined that lives rent free in my brain called the ‚Äúcockup cascade‚Äù. This happens more often in the open world syndicate bases, where if you mess up the stealth it will alert the whole area, an alarm will sound, and enemies will constantly come pouring out of noninteractable doorways to the point where it‚Äôs not worth the time. I once reloaded a save and saw that I lost about ten minutes, including having made purchases from a nearby vendor and some progress to a new Nix ability. There‚Äôs aspects to the game that incentivize heavy use of save scumming, which I don‚Äôt like. It reminds me of attempting old racing games where if you get spun out you may as well restart the entire match. 

I‚Äôm almost afraid to admit how much of my current hour count is from the card game. I don‚Äôt fully comprehend how it all works but the rush of winning after two or three failed attempts is incredibly exciting, but I‚Äôm not looking forward to one of the DLC‚Äôs where it‚Äôs highly Sabaac focused. It‚Äôs become a sort of night capper for me before bed where I go find a table to play a couple games.

There‚Äôs a lot of charm here. I like how people shift a bit when Nix bounces off of them when I send him to pickpocket, and the little animation of having a blaster rifle in his mouth. I like being able to find a ventilation shaft that helps me maneuver through encounters. I like driving by vistas that stop me in my tracks and make me go ‚Äúwhoa.‚Äù I like breaking into syndicate vaults. There‚Äôs some Ubijank here but I think the reputation of the game was a little harsh. I got it recently on a decent sale so my opinion may be cushioned by the lower cost. A solid 7/10 game, nothing that will change your life but if you like a general stealth/shooty loop, Ubisoft can and has done much worse. This ain‚Äôt that bad.
fIne game. Not incredible, but not bad neither.
stay as far far away as you can from this pile of garbage!
This game has the worst platforming known to mankind

CAVEAT EMPTOR. This gynocentric, estrogren-soaked abortion illustrates exactly why game companies shouldn't allow activists  to take over. They worry about representation and inclusion more than good or believable stories. 95% of the important NPCs, quest givers, gang leaders - even stormtroopers seem to be women and they wedge in minorities wherever they can. All mechanics are women, all bartenders are women, I'm sure the mens room attendants are women too. Men, especially white men, are always criminals.  Its noticeably lopsided to the point of parody and once you notice it, you cant stop - it becomes so predictable. Unless you are retarded or a professional protester this game will irritate the shit out of you and probably cause you to grow breasts from exposure.  Its an insult to pre-Dizney Star Wars fans. Mods cant even save it and I havent even mentioned the abysmal game play, design and endless bugs.. 
Ubisoft has become a pathetic joke in the industry. Without Russians & Arabs stepping in to save the company they would have deservedly gone bankrupt.

This game is awesome. At least now. Can't speak for launch because I wasn't there. 

The characters are endearing, the story is super fun. The visuals are incredible. The syndicate system is fun. The stealth (while simple) is fun and rewarding, the gunplay is good. I loved it. I'd you enjoy star wars or just action adventures i HIGHLY recommend

I am not a fan of Star Wars, and I haven‚Äôt seen any Star Wars movie. I stumbled upon this little game by accident and was very surprised. I find it to be a great filler while waiting for the next Mass Effect, similarly to Gears of War 5. Additionally, this is the first game that implemented frame generation very well. On my low-end hardware, the base frame rate is 25‚Äì30 fps, and it still looks and plays great on a big 144 Hz screen ‚Äì FG√ó4!

It is far from perfect and comes with Ubisoft malware, but I had a lot of fun with it, and that is what counts, I guess.

Thought it was a great Star Wars game. 
It has some cool areas with a great atmosphere.

reviews.developer_response:
Hi there Andy. I‚Äôm sorry to hear that you‚Äôre experiencing frequent crashing issues in Star Wars Outlaws. I understand this is not an ideal experience, and I‚Äôve outlined a few troubleshooting steps below that should help resolve the issue.

- Installing Star Wars Outlaws on the same SSD as both Steam and Ubisoft Connect is the most [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000109505] optimised way [/url] to run the game
- [url=http://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/929135/how-to-perform-a-clean-boot-in-windows] Clean boot [/url] will rule out any background processes that could be conflicting (Overwolf, Steel Series, Corsair, iCue3, Razer, Synapse, etc.)
- Unplug non-essential peripherals (steering wheels and pedals, streaming equipment, additional monitors, VR equipment, etc.)
- Clear the [url=https://help.steampowered.com/en/faqs/view/6ad7-820d-8be5-e51f] Steam cache [/url] and [url=www.ubisoft.com/help?article=000061966] Ubisoft Connect cache [/url]
- Complete [url=www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000061047] all these steps in this FAQ [/url] as these can cross off more common causes for crashing
- Reinstall the [url=www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000062655] supporting software [/url] for the game
- [url=https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/use-the-system-file-checker-tool-to-repair-missing-or-corrupted-system-files-79aa86cb-ca52-166a-92a3-966e85d4094e] Perform a SFC Scan [/url] if errors are detected, repeat the scan until all results are clear)
- [url=https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/windows/latest-supported-vc-redist?view=msvc-170] Clean reinstall the C++ supporting software [/url]

If these steps don't resolve the crashing issues for you, please [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help?article=000075524] link your Discord and Ubisoft accounts [/url] and join the [url=https://discord.com/invite/ubisoftofficial] Ubisoft Support Discord server [/url] so that we can take a deeper look.

reviews.review: Bought it on sale for 25 bucks deluxe edition. Addicted to it. If you are a star wars fan and a fan of open world and exploration.. 1000 percent a must buy. I see alot of negative reviews and honestly I have no idea what the hate is about.. 0 crashes on my end no problems at all. 32 hrs in. Love the story. Graphics are amazing. Open world with multiple open worlds are beautiful. Yet to even go to tattooine. Best star wars game I have played myself in years.

[h1]STAR WARS OUTLAWS[/h1]

The most recent, much maligned, and not hugely popular Star Wars game. 
Was it worth the hate? TLDR: [spoiler]Ehh... somewhat, yeah? Buy it at a big discount if you like Star Wars as a setting, and/or Tomb Raider-style games.[/spoiler]
Let's start with - 

[h3]THE GOOD:[/h3] The core gameplay loop is very satisfying when it's performing well. Sneaking through areas, stealing everything you can put your hands (or pet's teeth) on, killing guards that you can't avoid, or going loud when you feel like it or mess up. It feels like you're always improvising when you're in serious combat, which is absolutely a good thing, and intended. The main gimmick of your pet 'Nix' is actually pretty well implemented and is fun to use (most of the time - more on that in a minute). He can bite enemies, pickpocket them, break stuff, open things - it's a pretty decent system. There's a vast array of areas and biomes, zones and vaults to do this across, and the level design tends (again, more in a minute) to be pretty good. This core gameplay is broken up by a wide array of side activities which tend to be alright, though certain things like Sabaac will not be to everyone's taste. Space combat feels fine, not exceptional, but fine. Progression to me felt fine, but really if you have no taste for side activities it may treat you worse than me. [b]Just racing through the main story is really not the way to go.[/b] The story and side stories have their moments of genuine tension or other decent parts, but unfortunately, that's about all I have to say about that in the "good" category. 
All in all, this is a pretty decent list of things to have going for a game. So why am I on the fence about recommending it? Because of - 

[h3]THE BAD:[/h3] We will start right out of the gate with what is by far the biggest negative this game has going for it - the STANK of JANK. This game is absolutely LACED with jank, and it is immensely frustrating, because it is always lurking to disrupt your plans or ruin your immersion at the worst times. Trying to find the exact right pixel to stand on to initiate conversations with some of the NPCs in some scenarios. Trying to pick up the right item on a crowded floor in a hurry during combat when seconds count. Parkour feeling clunky ALL the time, and your character missing ledges or sliding off of stuff that it really feels like you should have grabbed or landed on. Carefully aiming a critical shot from behind cover, and having your reticle light up red, only to pull the trigger and hit some random piece of bullshit terrain, thereby alerting every guard in the vicinity to your presence and ruining your quiet approach. Guards randomly seeing or spotting stuff that it feels like they shouldn't have. Guards NOT seeing or hearing stuff that it feels like they should have. Finding a perfect hiding spot and preparing to send Nix to go cause some mischief - only to realize that the angle makes it impossible to control him. Perhaps worst of all, being in the middle of a big, cinematic mission only to realize the door button or other thing you need to move forward hasn't loaded properly, forcing you to reload a save, lose progress, and totally break your flow to progress. The game, in short, just does not feel polished at all, and keep in mind that this review (and playthrough it is based on) is way after release. This is absolutely brutal because it often totally ruins what would otherwise be really, genuinely good gameplay. This is the core sin of Star Wars Outlaws, and it is a tough one to swallow. 
There are some other complaints to go with it, though - 
Level design and parkour: while the level design is pretty good, it tends to be a bit 'railroad-ey.' What do I mean? Almost every mini-area in the open world that is a restricted zone or other place a thief would be trying to get has about two entrances: the front door, and the totally-not-obviously-badly-secured-back-or-side-or-vent entrance screaming PLEASE GO IN HERE. While you tend to have a decent amount of agency on how you do business once you're IN a level, how you GET IN a level has essentially no nuance to it at all. It might be a minor gripe to some people, but I couldn't help but think back to titles like AC Unity with nearly infinite ways to get through a place, and how poorly this compared. And on the topic of parkour, for a game that seems like it should really have climbing as a major element, it's pretty shocking how much stuff you simply... can't climb. Most buildings - no. Most rocks - no. Kay slides right off them like hot butter. Climbing is allowed in designated yellow paint areas only, and nowhere else (on the topic of yellow paint; there's more of it than I'd like. There's literally arrows pointing to where you need to go in many cases.). 
We will spoiler the story (and general narrative tone) complaints just in case anyone cares: 
[spoiler]The story, unfortunately, is usually pretty predictable. Every character that you think will betray you or have a change of heart and work with you will do so. Every job that you think will go sideways will. Most of the side characters are just forgettable tropes - we have droid guy, who fucking loves droids and has no other characteristics. Bomb girl, who fucking loves bombs and doesn't really have much else going on. Rebellion guy(s), who will not shut up about their moral high ground over everyone else, and also (you guessed it) do not have any other real traits. Your player character is not too much better, and spends the entire game bitter at almost everyone (yet somehow too friendly), and cocky (yet needs constant reassurance and handholding). Kay Vess is totally selfish, but then acts on other people's behalf randomly, without warning, and while I'm sure it was intended to feel like character development, it doesn't read that way to me. It just feels inconsistent. 
The narrative tone, as well, is a bit frustrating, and while this part is definitely my personal opinion, I wish that the franchise would take the kid gloves off just a little bit with the writing, especially characters like Kay Vess. The reality is that Kay Vess is a thief. She is out for herself, she's been surrounded by petty crime her entire life, and she grew up on a rough planet with almost no one to look out for her. Why is she so appalled by killing or double crossing/a general lack of loyalty among criminals (especially when the player character has the opportunity to kill hundreds and betray every single employer that they get)? Why is she punching stormtroopers in the head with her bare hands (and why is it working)? She should be carrying a vibroknife or other lethal melee weapon (a baton? something?), and she should be killing people in cold blood. She should know that business is business - obviously, everyone is trying to pull one over on the next guy.[/spoiler]
Lastly, while I don't love to harp on 'woke' in games, if you hate 'woke' you should absolutely skip this title. You'd think the galaxy was suffering some sort of horrible, multi-species genetic crisis the way that every single character that you interact with is female (literally about 85%), and the male characters are reserved for the absolute worst villains in the story, or random cannon fodder. It is girlboss simulator, and I don't mean that in a positive sense. 

[h1]So what's the verdict?[/h1]
There's a game that could have been genuinely really good hiding under A LOT of problems - if you like games of this type, or Star Wars (especially if you want to get away from force users), this game might be worth playing anyway. It's good for about 50 hours of mixed gameplay, longer if you want to do more side content. If you wait for a discount, I'd say it's probably worth $10-$20, depending on how much it interests you. I got it for about $20, and I don't really regret it, and so at the end of the day, I guess it's a recommend from me. 

Best of luck to you, snoldiers.
